definitions.definition: to make objects, patterns, etc. by cutting away material from a piece of wood or stone, or another hard material
definitions.sensetop: carve somethingcarve something from/out of somethingcarve something into/in somethingcarve in something
definitions.labels: (figurative)(US English)(US English)(US English)(especially British English)(North American English usually)(British English)(North American English)

examples.text: The statue was carved out of a single piece of stone.
The beads were carved from solid ivory.
The wood had been carved into the shape of a flower.
Over the centuries, melting snow had carved valleys in the landscape.
She carves in both stone and wood.

definitions.definition: to write something on a surface by cutting into it

examples.text: They carved their initials on the desk.
A Latin inscription had been carved on the lid of the box.

definitions.definition: to cut a large piece of cooked meat into smaller pieces for eating

examples.text: Who's going to carve the turkey?
Lunch is ready. Who's going to carve?
She taught me how to carve a leg of lamb.
We watched as the waiter expertly carved the duck.

definitions.definition: to work hard in order to have a successful career, reputation, etc.

examples.text: He succeeded in carving out a career in the media.
She has carved a place for herself in the fashion world.
People should remember that our proposals aren't set in stone.
These rules are not set in stone.

wordOrigin: Old English ceorfan ‘cut, carve’, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch kerven.
